sen.j: 閑院宮典仁親王（かんいんのみやすけひとしんのう、享保18年2月17日（1733年4月1日） - 寛政6年7月6日（1794年8月1日））は、江戸時代の宮家当主で皇族。
sen.e: Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Sukehito (April 1st, 1733 - August 1st, 1794) was the princely house and the Imperial family from Edo period.
Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Sukehito (April 1st, 1733 - August 1st, 1794) was the family head of the Imperial prince houshold in Edo period and member of the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: I don't understand how a "prince" can be a "house" ("princely house"-a strange term) "princely house" needs to be defined in order to rewrite this sentence correctly.「宮家」の訳を変え、「当主」のニュアンスが出るように訳し直しました。
sen.e: Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Sukehito (April 1, 1733 - August 1, 1794) was the head of the Miyake (house of an imperial prince) in Edo period and member of the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: 日付表記"Imperial Prince household"→"Miyake (house of an imperial prince) "に変更しました。

sen.j: 幼名は寿宮（ひさのみや）。
sen.e: His childhood name was Hisanomiya.
His childhood name was Hisanomiya.
His childhood name was Hisanomiya.

sen.j: 世襲親王家、閑院宮第二代当主。
sen.e: He was the second head of the Kaninnomiya family and was from hereditary Imperial family.
He was the second head of the Kaninnomiya family and was from the hereditary Imperial family.
He was the second head of the Kaninnomiya family and was from the hereditary Imperial family.

sen.j: 慶光天皇または慶光院の前名。
sen.e: His former name was Emperor Kyoko or Kyokoin.
His former name was Emperor Kyoko or Kyokoin.
His former name was Emperor Kyoko or Kyokoin.

sen.j: 閑院宮典仁親王の呼びかたは江戸期のもので、明治期以後は慶光天皇という。
sen.e: The way to pronounce Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Sukehito was from Edo period, he was called Emperor Kyoko after Meiji period.
Imperial Prince Sukehito lived during the Edo period, and later he was given the title Emperor Kyoko after the the end of Meiji period.
sen.cmt: deleted "The way to pronounce" as it is meaningless in the context of this sentence. "after" or "during" " the Meiji period?" please clarify.「呼びかた」のニュアンスが伝わるように、「明治期以後」のイメージがはっきりするように訳し直しました。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Sukehito lived during the Edo period, and later he was given the title Emperor Kyoko after the end of Meiji period.

sen.j: 古今伝授伝承者に名を連ねる和歌の名手で、能書家でもあり、短冊などの遺墨は、たいへん貴重。
sen.e: He was the talented poet of Waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) who was one of the popular poet of oral tradition in Kokindenju, also known as a good penman and there is his very rare calligraphy in black paint in Tanzaku. (a (long) strip of paper)

He was a talented poet of Waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) who was one of the popular poets of oral tradition in the Kokindenju, he was also known to be good with a brush and an very rare example of his calligraphy in black paint exists in Tanzaku. (a long sheet on which Waka poems are written)
sen.cmt: I think calligraphy is done with a "brush," not a "pen" What is a long strip of paper?「短冊」の説明を修正しました。
sen.e: He was a talented poet of Waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) who was one of the popular poets of oral tradition in the Kokindenju, he was also known to be good with a brush and an very rare example of his calligraphy in black paint exists in Tanzaku (a long sheet on which Waka poems are written).
He was Emperor Kokaku's father.
He was Emperor Kokaku's father.
He was Emperor Kokaku's father.

sen.j: 墓所は天皇号が追尊されたため「陵」を名乗っている。
sen.e: His cemetery is called as Mausoleum as he was given posthumous honorific title of Emperor.
His place of entombment is called as Mausoleum as he was given the posthumous honorific title of Emperor.
His place of entombment is called as Mausoleum as he was given the posthumous honorific title of Emperor.

sen.j: 陵は廬山寺陵（京都市上京区）。
sen.e: His mausoleum is in Rozan-ji no Misasagi. (the Rozan-ji mausoleum) (Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City)
His mausoleum is located in Rozan-ji no Misasagi. (the Rozan-ji mausoleum) (Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City)
His mausoleum is located in Rozan-ji no Misasagi (the Rozan-ji mausoleum) (Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City).
Genealogy
Genealogy
Genealogy

sen.j: 東山天皇の孫で、閑院宮直仁親王の第二王子。
sen.e: He was Emperor Higashiyama's grandchild and the second Prince of Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Naohito.
He was Emperor Higashiyama's grandchild and the second Prince of Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Naohito.
He was Emperor Higashiyama's grandchild and the second Prince of Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Naohito.

sen.j: 養母は関白近衛基熙の娘、藤原脩子。
sen.e: His foster mother was Chancellor, Motohiro KONOE's daughter, FUJIWARA no Shushi.
His foster mother was Chancellor, Motohiro KONOE's daughter, FUJIWARA no Shushi.
His foster mother was Chancellor, Motohiro KONOE's daughter, FUJIWARA no Shushi.
His birth mother was Ie no Nyobo (a lady in waiting), Sanuki.
sen.cmt: 家女房→Ie no Nyobo(a lady-in-waiting)[定訳不明]
sen.e: His birth mother was Ie no Nyobo (a lady in waiting), Sanuki.
His birth mother was Ie no Nyobo (a lady in waiting), Sanuki.

sen.j: 御息所は中御門天皇の第五皇女、成子内親王。
sen.e: His Miyasudokoro (wife) was Emperor Nakamikado's fifth Princess, Imperial Prince Fusako.
His Miyasudokoro (wife) was Emperor Nakamikado's fifth Princess, Imperial Prince Fusako.
His Miyasudokoro (wife) was Emperor Nakamikado's fifth Princess, Imperial Prince Fusako.
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 朝廷では、1779年に後桃園天皇が男子を残さないままに崩御してしまった為、典仁親王の第六皇子として生まれた師仁親王（兼仁親王）が、急遽即位（光格天皇）となった。
sen.e: In the Imperial Palace, since Emperor Gomomozono died without having prince to be his successor, Imperial Prince Sukehito's sixth Prince, Imperial Prince Morohito (Tomohito) succeeded to the throne in haste. (Emperor Kokaku)

Since Emperor Gomomozono died without having a prince to become his successor, Imperial Prince Sukehito's sixth Prince, Imperial Prince Morohito (Tomohito) succeeded to the throne in haste. (Emperor Kokaku)

Since Emperor Gomomozono died in 1779 without having a prince to become his successor, Imperial Prince Sukehito's sixth Prince, Imperial Prince Morohito (Tomohito) succeeded to the throne in haste (Emperor Kokaku).
sen.cmt: 「1779年に」を訳出しました。ピリオドの位置移動

sen.j: 父である典仁親王の宮中での地位が大臣より低い事から、太上天皇の尊号を贈ろうとしたが、江戸幕府老中・松平定信などに反対され、贈る事はできなかった（尊号一件）。
sen.e: Since his father, Imperial Prince Sukehito's rank in the Imperial Palace was lower than the Minister, he attempted to send the respect title of the retired emperor to him but he could not do so, since the Senior Councilor of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA was ageist it.

Since his father, (Imperial Prince Sukehito's rank in the Imperial Palace was lower than Minister), attempted to give him the respected title of "retired emperor," he could not do so, because the Senior Councilor of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA was against it.

Since his father, Imperial Prince Sukehito's rank in the Imperial Palace was lower than Minister, the respected title of the retired emperor was about to be given to Imperial Prince Sukehito, but he did not receive it, since the Senior Councilor of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA was ageist it. (Songo ikken - Songo Incident)
sen.cmt: 原文自体分かりにくいですが、he は誰を指すのか明確にし、訳しなおしました。Songo ikken (Songo Incident) を追加しました。

sen.j: 1884年（明治17年）になり、明治天皇の高祖父にあたるという事で「慶光天皇」の諡号と「太上天皇」の尊号が贈られた（明治以後に「太上天皇」制度が廃止された関係で二重の手続を要した）、以後、閑院宮典仁親王ではなく、慶光天皇または慶光院と称される。
sen.e: In 1884, he was given the posthumous name of 'Emperor Kyoko' and the respect title of 'the retired emperor', being Emperor Meiji's great great grandfather, (The procedure to do this was a lot more complicated since the system of having 'the retired emperor' was abolished after Meiji period) after that he was called Emperor Kyoko or Kyokoin, instead of Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Sukehito.

In 1884, he was given the posthumous name of 'Emperor Kyoko' and the respected title of 'retired emperor,' being Emperor Meiji's great great grandfather, (The procedure to do this was a lot more complicated since the system of having a 'the retired emperor' was abolished after Meiji period) so, after that he was called Emperor Kyoko or Kyokoin, instead of Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Sukehito.

In 1884, he was given the posthumous name of 'Emperor Kyoko' and the respected title of 'retired emperor,' being Emperor Meiji's great great grandfather, (The procedure to do this was a lot more complicated since the system of having a 'the retired emperor' was abolished after Meiji period) so, after that he was called Emperor Kyoko or Kyokoin, instead of Kaninnomiya Imperial Prince Sukehito.
